dt: {bc}the act of an authority (such as a government) by which pardon is granted to a large group of individuals

dt.t: The government granted {wi}amnesty{/wi} to all political prisoners.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}amnēstia,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}amnēstía{/it} "forgetfulness, oblivion, deliberate overlooking of past offenses," from {it}amnēstós{/it} "forgotten, forgetful" (from {it}a-{/it} {et_link|a-:2|a-:2} + {it}mnēstós{/it} "memorable," verbal adjective of {it}mnáomai, mnâsthai{/it} "to be mindful of" and {it}mimnḗskomai, mimnḗskesthai{/it} "to call to mind, remember") + {it}-ia{/it} {et_link|-y:2|-y:2} {ma}{mat|mind:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: the act of an authority (such as a government) by which pardon is granted to a large group of individuals

dt: {bc}to grant {d_link|amnesty|amnesty:1} to {bc}to pardon (someone) officially often before a trial or conviction

dt.t: Only last Thursday Mr. Clinton told the U.S. that the generals were responsible for the killings … Now, they are to be {wi}amnestied{/wi} and allowed to remain in Haiti if they so wish.

Traditionally, the incoming president {wi}amnesties{/wi} all outstanding driving offences: during the months before an election people park even more selfishly than usual and drive at unbelievable speeds, knowing if they're caught, they'll be {wi}amnestied{/wi}.

shortdef: to grant amnesty to : to pardon (someone) officially often before a trial or conviction
